Description: Scarab carved from cream-coloured steatite; well-defined back with detailed clypeus and head, prothorax and elytra marked respectively by double and single incised lines, and small triangles at junction with prothorax indicating humeral callosities; feathering on front legs indicated with numerous parallel finely incised lines; side view unknown; underside incised with representation of Horus as a falcon looking towards the right, wearing the double crown, and standing on the rectangular frame decorated with vertical lines ('serekh'-pattern of palace facade), with a raised uraeus in front of him and a sun-disc with uraeus behind; motif representing the royal Horus Name; further incised details within falcon figure and palace facade; longitudinally pierced.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Possibly one of the six scarabs from the Scarab Factory mentioned in the EEF distribution list Philadelphia under no. 38.

This finely made scarab belongs probably to Gorton's type VIII, a type well attested on Punic and Etruscan sites in the West, as well as in Greece and Cyprus (Gorton 1996, type VIII, 23-7). Gorton suggested that such scarabs were produced in Memphis, from the 8th till the 7th c. BC (Gorton 1996, 27). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OA.29) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia
